title: MAGGIC Risk Calculator for Heart Failure
description: Estimates 1- and 3-year mortality in heart failure patients

parameters.name: ace_arb
parameters.description: Currently prescribed ACE inhibitor or ARB

ranges.interpretation: Low risk for 1-year (<5%) and 3-year (<15%) mortality. Standard heart failure management appropriate.
Intermediate risk for 1-year (5-15%) and 3-year (15-40%) mortality. Consider optimized medical therapy and monitoring.
High risk for 1-year (15-40%) and 3-year (40-70%) mortality. Aggressive management and advanced therapies may be indicated.
Very high risk for 1-year (>40%) and 3-year (>70%) mortality. Consider advanced heart failure therapies, transplant evaluation, or palliative care.

references: Pocock SJ, Ariti CA, McMurray JJ, Maggioni A, Køber L, Squire IB, et al. Predicting survival in heart failure: a risk score based on 39 372 patients from 30 studies. Eur Heart J. 2013 May;34(19):1404-13. doi: 10.1093/eurheartj/ehs337.

Sartipy U, Dahlström U, Edner M, Lund LH. Predicting survival in heart failure: validation of the MAGGIC heart failure risk score in 51,043 patients from the Swedish heart failure registry. Eur J Heart Fail. 2014 Feb;16(2):173-9. doi: 10.1111/ejhf.32.

Simpson J, Jhund PS, Silva Cardoso J, Martinez F, Mosterd A, Ramires F, et al. Comparing LCZ696 with enalapril according to baseline risk using the MAGGIC and EMPHASIS-HF risk scores: an analysis of mortality and morbidity in PARADIGM-HF. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2015 Nov 10;66(19):2059-71. doi: 10.1016/j.jacc.2015.08.878.
formula: Complex integer scoring system based on 13 predictors: age, gender, EF, NYHA class, creatinine, systolic BP, BMI, diabetes, COPD, smoking, HF duration, beta-blocker use, ACE-I/ARB use
notes: Developed from meta-analysis of 39,372 patients from 30 studies
Applicable to both HFrEF and HFpEF patients
Score ranges from 0 (lowest risk) to 50+ (highest risk)
Does not include biomarkers like BNP/NT-proBNP
Age scoring varies by ejection fraction category
Lower EF, higher creatinine, and diabetes are strongest predictors
Not prescribed beta-blockers or ACE-I/ARB increases risk
Useful for clinical decision-making and prognostication
